Topic.Title: Can I still edit my game if I publish it?

Posts.EditableText: Guys, I am making a game about Pokemon Fire Red. I have only made choices for Charmander. And made the game up to Viridian city. Could I publish my game and still be able to edit it?
Posts.HTML: Guys, I am making a game about Pokemon Fire Red. I have only made choices for Charmander. And made the game up to Viridian city. Could I publish my game and still be able to edit it?

Posts.EditableText: Yes. But you need to republish it after you've made changes to it.
Posts.HTML: Yes. But you need to republish it after you've made changes to it.

Posts.EditableText: And the players' save games will not get updated.
Posts.HTML: And the players' save games will not get updated.

Posts.EditableText: Thank you for your help! I would now publish my game:  Pokemon Red Adventure!
Posts.HTML: Thank you for your help! I would now publish my game: Pokemon Red Adventure!

Posts.EditableText: Player saves wont be updated?  How come?  What if the change was only minor like no matter how much you and other play tested it, you still find spelling mistakes, or you want to add a picture to go along with a room.  That update alone destroys all saves for your player base?
Posts.HTML: Player saves wont be updated? How come? What if the change was only minor like no matter how much you and other play tested it, you still find spelling mistakes, or you want to add a picture to go along with a room. That update alone destroys all saves for your player base?

Posts.EditableText:
Yep, in most cases.  That’s why I download pretty much every game on here.  There are some work arounds that some authors have come up with but I cannot give advice on that.

In X3, I am coding “cheats” to jump forward to certain spots in the game in case I must edit it and republish.  I wouldn’t expect smaller games to worry about this however.
Posts.HTML:
Yep, in most cases. That’s why I download pretty much every game on here. There are some work arounds that some authors have come up with but I cannot give advice on that.

In X3, I am coding “cheats” to jump forward to certain spots in the game in case I must edit it and republish. I wouldn’t expect smaller games to worry about this however.

Posts.EditableText: But what makes a save break from something so nonsequential as a spelling correction or a photo or hyperlink added?
Posts.HTML: But what makes a save break from something so nonsequential as a spelling correction or a photo or hyperlink added?

Posts.EditableText:
When a player saves a game, they save everything. Everything in Quest is an object with attributes, and potentially all those attributes could change. So Quest saves the lot. In effect, playing the game is like editing and saving your own version of it. 

When the player loads a saved game, Quest does not do anything with the original (or your revised version). It just loads the save game, because all the data is there.
Posts.HTML:
When a player saves a game, they save everything. Everything in Quest is an object with attributes, and potentially all those attributes could change. So Quest saves the lot. In effect, playing the game is like editing and saving your own version of it.

When the player loads a saved game, Quest does not do anything with the original (or your revised version). It just loads the save game, because all the data is there.

Posts.EditableText:
But people's games do not automatically update do they?  I mean they have to physically make the effort to update the game themselves right?  I could have notices for mine at least.

And can authors have two separate versions of the same game, like one with and one without the update?
Posts.HTML:
But people's games do not automatically update do they? I mean they have to physically make the effort to update the game themselves right? I could have notices for mine at least.

And can authors have two separate versions of the same game, like one with and one without the update?

Posts.EditableText:
“And can authors have two separate versions of the same game, like one with and one without the update?“

Yes.  You just have to create a new game ID in the GUI and publish that.  

Someone correct me if I’m wrong here.
Posts.HTML:
“And can authors have two separate versions of the same game, like one with and one without the update?“

Yes. You just have to create a new game ID in the GUI and publish that.

Someone correct me if I’m wrong here.

Posts.EditableText:
> But people's games do not automatically update do they?

No. You need to publish (and upload for desktop).
Posts.HTML:
But people's games do not automatically update do they?

No. You need to publish (and upload for desktop).

Posts.EditableText: Wouldn't editing the game ID make a new game... or a gigantic error?
Posts.HTML: Wouldn't editing the game ID make a new game... or a gigantic error?

Posts.EditableText:
>Wouldn't editing the game ID make a new game... or a gigantic error?

No.  Quest treats a new game ID as a new game entirely.  It can be identical (or altered) and it will appear as two separate games.
Posts.HTML:
Wouldn't editing the game ID make a new game... or a gigantic error?

No. Quest treats a new game ID as a new game entirely. It can be identical (or altered) and it will appear as two separate games.
